properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today into tonight. Snow squalls are expected to intermittently affect the area until Saturday. Snowfall amounts near 5 cm are possible today with an additional 2 to 5 cm possible tonight. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall will continue through this evening. Total snowfall amounts: 15 to 25 cm. Location: Halifax Metro and Halifax County West. Time span: ending mid evening. Remarks: Snow has begun to rapidly accumulate in some areas of Halifax County late this afternoon. Heavy snowfall will continue through the evening commute into the mid part of the evening, with total accumulations of up to 25 cm expected in inland areas which see the heaviest snowfall rates. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow is expected Saturday night and Sunday morning for Central Coast - Coastal Sections, Vancouver Island, Sunshine Coast and Lower Mainland. A cool airmass and low pressure system will slide along coastal B.C. on Saturday. Snow is forecast to begin Saturday night and continue into Sunday. By Sunday afternoon snow will become mixed with rain in many areas. Potential snowfall accumulation varies from 2 to 5 cm for most of the Lower Mainland, the Sunshine Coast, inland sections of western Vancouver Island and for Central Coast - Coastal Sections. Eastern and inland areas of Vancouver Island are most likely to see the highest amounts of snow, with accumulations from 5 to 15 cm, especially above 200 metres; this includes the Malahat Highway. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-23T04:32:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-22T12:33:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3031644196.2021
Area: North Vancouver Island, East Vancouver Island - Duncan to Nanaimo, East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay, East Vancouver Island - Courtenay to Campbell River, West Vancouver Island, Inland Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections, Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove, Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River, Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - central including the City of Vancouver Burnaby and New Westminster, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge, Metro Vancouver - southeast including Surrey and Langley, Metro Vancouver - southwest including Richmond and Delta

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow is expected Saturday night and Sunday morning for Central Coast - Coastal Sections, Vancouver Island, Sunshine Coast and Lower Mainland. A cool airmass and low pressure system will slide along coastal B.C. on Saturday. Snow is forecast to begin Saturday night and continue into Sunday. By Sunday afternoon snow will become mixed with rain in many areas. Potential snowfall accumulation varies from 2 to 5 cm for most of the Lower Mainland, the Sunshine Coast, inland sections of western Vancouver Island and for Central Coast - Coastal Sections. Eastern and inland areas of Vancouver Island are most likely to see the highest amounts of snow, with accumulations from 5 to 15 cm, especially above 200 metres; this includes the Malahat Highway. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 centimetres combined with strong northwesterly winds will give winter storm conditions over these regions Saturday evening and Sunday. These conditions will cause blowing snow reducing visibilities especially Saturday night into Sunday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of snow are expected Saturday night through Monday morning, with the potential for significant snowfall Sunday night. The first round of snow is expected to be fairly light. Snow will begin Saturday night with a few cm accumulating by Sunday morning. The snow will be wet and may become mixed with rain Sunday afternoon as temperatures rise above freezing. A more significant round of snow is possible beginning late Sunday afternoon. Current guidance suggests snowfall amounts near 10 cm Sunday night. However, with temperatures hovering near freezing the snow will be wet and slushy. If it is slightly warmer than expected, snow is likely to change over to rain. While there is still some uncertainty in the forecast, wet and slushy snow may make for a messy commute Monday morning. Power outages are also possible if heavy, wet snow accumulates on trees. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-23T10:31:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-22T18:32:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2703520663.2021
Area: Fraser Valley - west including Abbotsford, Fraser Valley - central including Chilliwack, Fraser Valley - east including Hope
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow and blowing snow are expected at times throughout this weekend. Locations: southeastern Labrador from Rigolet to Lodge Bay. Additional snowfall: 30 to 50 cm (tonight through Sunday) in coastal communities; locally 60 to 100 cm inland and over higher terrain. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly near 70 km/h at times. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will ease somewhat on Saturday (especially over areas south of Black Tickle), but is expected to become heavy again Saturday night into Sunday. Northeasterly winds will strengthen tonight and then ease over some areas on Saturday, but will become strong again over all locations on Sunday. A general improving trend is expected to commence Sunday night. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Road closures are possible. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-23T11:54:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-22T19:55:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3991100572.2021
Area: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Rigolet and vicinity

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall today. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm, likely higher in some areas of heaviest snow bands. Locations: Annapolis, Kings, and Halifax counties. Time span: ending this evening. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, is falling across parts of Nova Scotia today as a small but vigorous weather system develops and passes just off the Atlantic coast. Given the nature of this system, the location of heaviest snowfall is difficult to pin down, and as such this statement may need to be extended to additional regions or upgraded to a snowfall warning for some areas. Regardless, the timing of the snow will likely have impacts on the evening commute in the Halifax Regional Municipality and the surrounding areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring. Locations: Trans-Labrador Highway from Kenamu River to Cartwright Junction. Additional expected snowfall: 20 to 40 cm (tonight through Sunday night). Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 70 km/h (Saturday afternoon through Sunday evening). Remarks: A prolonged period of light to moderate snowfall will produce significant total accumulations by the end of this weekend. As winds strengthen on Saturday, visibilities will deteriorate in blowing snow. The winds are expected ease Sunday night. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-23T11:49:13-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in blowing snow is expected or occurring. Locations: Postville - Makkovik. Additional expected snowfall: 10 to 20 cm (tonight through Sunday night), with higher amounts inland and over elevated terrain. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly 80 km/h (Saturday afternoon through Sunday night). Remarks: A prolonged period of light to moderate snowfall will combine with strong northeasterly winds this weekend to produce poor visibilities in blowing snow. Blizzard-like conditions may occur inland and over elevated terrain, where accumulations will likely be substantially higher. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

Description: Long-lived snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will rapidly accumulate. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Road closures are likely. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-23T07:35:28-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lived snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will rapidly accumulate. Snow squalls will intermittently affect the area until Saturday afternoon. Snow squalls will intensify tonight. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected tonight with an additional of 10 cm possible on Saturday. Snow squalls are expected to taper off late Saturday. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Road closures are likely. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
